Award.AwardTitle: Crossing the Threshold by Supporting Writing Transfer as Engaged Learning in Introductory Engineering Laboratories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project conducted at Washington State University Vancouver will help to improve the writing ability of engineering students. The project will focus on facilitating transfer of writing skills developed in first-year English composition classes into engineering courses. Writing is a critical skill needed by engineers and an ability frequently cited by industry as area in which graduates need improvement. The goal of this exploratory project is to investigate how an approach focusing on writing transfer enhances students' writing in technical courses.

The project will investigate the writing practices of engineering students as they move from first-year composition (FYC) courses into introductory engineering laboratory courses. The project will utilize a writing approach that emphasizes genre awareness rather than a traditional modes approach. Also included will be training for faculty and teaching assistants that introduces rhetorical approaches to writing and teaching for transfer. Analysis will include quantitative and qualitative data to inform the impact of the instructional modules as an effective intervention to support student learning. Key questions include identification of evidence of transfer of engineering students' rhetorical writing knowledge from first year composition into introductory engineering laboratory courses; and how knowledge of transfer mechanisms can inform pedagogical approaches and strategies to improve writing. The project is based on preliminary results which indicate a substantial percentage of engineering students do not improve in any rhetorical aspects (invention, rhetoric awareness, arrangement, and style) except convention, which is more related to disciplinary knowledge rather than rhetorical knowledge. This suggests that familiarity with the rhetorical characteristics of genre may be more productive than the traditional case study approach often employed in engineering writing instruction. Given the ubiquity of first-year English composition classes, the results of this work have the potential to be broadly applicable across undergraduate STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this exploratory project was to investigate how a pedagogical approach focusing on writing transfer enhances students’ writing performances at the threshold of entering engineering programs. Three specific objectives for this project were to 1) investigate the transfer of writing skills from first-year composition (FYC) assignments to laboratory reports written during introductory engineering laboratory courses; 2) develop and test instructional modules based on rhetorical theory and theories of transfer in order to promote written communication skills and disciplinary knowledge as engaged learning; and 3) provide faculty development training in a rhetorical approach to writing instruction and sound writing assessment instruments that will provide continuous pedagogical improvement.

 

Intellectual merits

The results from this exploratory investigation advanced the fundamental understanding of how far transfer of engineering students’ knowledge in writing occurs. The series of studies provided strong empirical evidence of a correlation between engineering students’ writing performances in FYC assignments and lab reports in introductory engineering lab courses. Although engineering students’ transfer of learning from FYC (English) to engineering courses can be defined as “far transfer” or “high-road transfer” due to the disciplinarily distinct features of these courses, we identified shared values and characteristics across FYC assignments and lab reports: the importance of audience awareness with a purpose in mind, a focus on critical thinking, use of sources to support claims, error-free prose, and the role of the writing process as engaged learning.

This exploratory research project yielded preliminary transfer-focused modules for both FYC and engineering lab instructors. After implementation of this preliminary lab report instructional module into five engineering lab courses at Washington State University Vancouver (WSU-V) and Clark College (CC), we collected statistically significant evidence of improved student lab report writing at both schools from pre- to post-test (independent t-test with total student number, n = 101, p <0.05). Mean scores improved with respect to the students’ technical audience awareness (by 29%), disciplinary critical thinking (by 23%), and engineering literacy conventions (by 22%). Engineering student focus group responses showed that students felt strongly that they were supported in the development of their lab report writing skills, and that they improved as writers in engineering. Reflecting on their experience, students observed that audience awareness and conventions should be adapted when encountering different writing contexts. Both quantitative and qualitative data suggest that using this innovative transfer-focused pedagogical strategy to develop students’ enhanced learning through writing is more effective than the traditional “mode” strategies. According to the interview results from the participating instructors, this transfer-focused approach also improved instructors’ understanding and teaching practices with respect to writing pedagogies.

The two workshops that we completed included a total of 30 participants from three institutions (WSU-V, CC, University of Portland) and local industry. Overall, evaluation results from the workshop reported that all participants from both English and engineering disciplines strongly agreed that excellence in writing pedagogy is very important to them, that they valued the writing transfer workshops as a source of professional development, that they were confident in their role as a teacher, and that they value continuous professional development.

 

Broadening impacts

The proposed project directly transformed five introductory engineering laboratory courses and two FYC courses in WSU-V and CC by implementing the developed instructional modules into participating courses. A total of 425 engineering students from both institutions were impacted by this project over three years. We developed an interdisciplinary learning community in writing transfer consisting of 30 people that included faculty and teaching assistants from Engineering and English.

Other 2-year and 4-year undergraduate writing and engineering programs will be able to adapt the developed modules into their FYC and introductory engineering laboratory courses without significant changes to their existing course contents. The project website for public dissemination of our educational materials for lab report writing instruction is available at https://labs.wsu.edu/writing-transfer-engineering/.

Dedicated to supporting diversity efforts in higher education, we successfully recruited and mentored undergraduate students of underrepresented groups via our Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Research team. We also conducted an outreach program for four MESA (Math Engineering Science Achievement) coaches from the regional middle/high schools. We trained the coaches on how to conduct engineering experiments and teach reports in their MESA classes designed for supporting underrepresented students in STEM (African Americans, Native Americans, Latinos, and women).

The PIs and other project participants have actively disseminated research results broadly to multiple audiences and venues. Venues included the professional conferences of American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE), the National Conference on College Composition and Communication (CCCC), the American Association for Applied Linguistics, and refereed publications for both research communities, including IEEE Journal of Technical Communications (under review), and Across the Disciplines: A Journal of Language, Learning, and Academic Writing (under review).
